awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Computationally-driven Design of Advanced Block Polymer Nanomaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: Block polymers are macromolecules that contain segments or 'blocks' of repeated polymerized monomers of at least two types. Much as proteins have tremendous variation in property and function in biological systems by virtue of the choice and placement of amino acid residues along the polymer backbone, the properties of block polymers can be widely tuned by varying the length, placement, and chemical identity of their constituent blocks. Block polymers are the basis for many important types of soft materials such as elastomers and adhesives, but are increasingly important in applications such as advanced membranes for batteries and fuel cells, medical devices, and soft templates for patterning microelectronic devices. A current challenge in deploying block polymers in such applications is that the chemical design space is vast and there is very limited data and predictive ability connecting the chemical structure to the derivative properties in a given material. This project aims to dramatically accelerate block polymer materials discovery by closely coupling modern theory and simulation approaches with state-of-the-art synthesis and characterization. Through extensive experimental feedback to validate and continuously improve models and simulation methods, the project will build the foundations for a future in which in silico design of block polymers is routine.

Technical Description: Block polymers are attractive for creating advanced materials with novel functionality by embedding multiple physical or chemical properties within a single compound. Such polymers are also attractive for manufacturing as their synthesis is scalable and they embed nanostructures spontaneously by thermodynamic driving forces arising from the incompatibility of the different blocks. However, as the demand for distinct desirable properties exhibited by a single material increases, so must the number of blocks. The corresponding design space increases geometrically with the number of blocks and block chemistries, making an intuition-based, trial-and-error approach infeasible. Instead, the project adopts a computationally-driven materials discovery approach, building on recent game-changing advances in self-consistent field theory and global optimization strategies for materials design and discovery. These computational strategies are coupled to an ambitious, advanced synthesis and characterization program capable of realizing the desired materials in practice. Through experimental feedback to validate and continuously improve models and simulation methods, the project will build the foundations for a future in which in silico design of block polymers is routine.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Polymers consist of repeated chemical units (monomers) bonded together to produce a long chain. To create a block polymer, two or more different polymers are bonded at their ends. Owing to their connectivity, most polymers cannot mix because the randomness gained by mixing is not sufficient to offset the chemical incompatibility between the monomers. Whereas polymer blends tend to phase separate, a neat melt of block polymers cannot undergo phase separation due to the covalent connections that tie the blocks together. Rather, block polymers spontaneously self-assemble into ordered structures that optimize the competition between minimizing the interfacial area in the ordered structure against the unfavorable effect of stretching the polymer chains in order to maintain constant density.

The major goal of this project was to discover block copolymer architectures and formulations that self- assemble into new nano-structured phases with symmetries and length-scales appropriate for applications to photonics. This is a collaborative research partnership between the University of Minnesota (UMN) and the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB). The UMN portion of the project focused on two key aspects of this overall goal. From the computational side, open-source tools were developed that automatically search through the different chemical possibilities to identify the most promising systems for experimentation, using an algorithm that mimics the way that insects search for food. Additional open-source tools were developed to visualize the results of those calculations. This software was used to predict polymer blend systems that can produce a Laves phase, a possible candidate for an optical material. The resulting phase behavior bears a striking resemblance to that observed in metal alloys, including the first prediction of a line compound in a polymer blend. These computational efforts were coupled with experimental work aimed at developing the synthetic tools required to realize the materials goals of the project. The first synthesis effort aimed at a strategy for synthesizing charged polymers via a method that first creates neutral polymers and then converts them into charged polymers in a post-polymerization modification, thereby circumventing the challenges that come when applying standard synthetic methods to create charged multiblock polymers. The second synthesis effort focused on methods to create multiblock bottle-brush copolymers. Owing to the crowding of the backbone by the side chains, bottle-brush polymers are stiff and their self-assembled nanoscale structures have large length scales than those available to linear block polymers. For photonic applications, such length scales are important to reach visible wavelengths, and the synthetic effort was driven by a prediction from the UCSB team about the properties of non-centrosymmetric lamellar systems.

In addition to these scientific impacts, the project provided training to six graduate students on computational aspects of the project and five postdoctoral researchers on experimental aspects of the project. The computational students gained experience in using advanced tools for simulating polymer phase behavior and high-performance computing. The experimental students gained experience in modern polymer synthesis and characterization. By working together on this project, computational researchers gained experience in the experimental aspects and vice versa. The students and postdoctoral researchers who have left Minnesota by the conclusion of this project have pursued careers in industry (3 graduate students, 3 postdocs), academia (1 postdoc) and government labs (1 postdoc), thereby contributing to the US workforce development. Outreach efforts included continued involvement with the Energy & U program at the University of Minnesota, which provides an entertaining and engaging introduction to thermodynamics to circa 10,000 K-12 students per year, then the Eureka! program, which introduces STEM to 7th and 8th grade girls.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/07/2022
Modified by: Kevin D Dorfman
